wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the prj-core system. Explain its purpose as a full-stack monorepo application with admin interface, mobile app, backend API server, and component development environment. Document the architectural vision, key components (admin, mobile, server, shared packages), and their relationships. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'monorepo', 'Turborepo', 'NestJS', and 'React Native'. Provide practical examples of how the different applications interact through shared packages. Document the overall workflow from development setup to deployment. Include diagrams illustrating the system architecture and component interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the prj-core monorepo architecture. Describe the high-level design using Turborepo for task orchestration and pnpm workspaces for package management. Document the component interactions between apps and packages, data flows, and integration patterns. Explain technical decisions behind the monorepo approach, trade-offs, and constraints. Include infrastructure requirements, scalability considerations, and deployment topology through Docker. Provide system context diagrams and component breakdowns showing how admin, mobile, server, and shared packages interact. Address cross-cutting concerns like shared configuration, environment management, and build optimization. Document technology stack, third-party dependencies, and version compatibility across the monorepo.

wiki_catalogs.name: Monorepo Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the monorepo structure of prj-core. Describe the high-level organization with apps and packages directories, explaining the separation between applications (admin, mobile, server, storybook) and shared reusable packages. Document the purpose and scope of each application and package, including their interdependencies and integration patterns. Explain how the structure supports code reuse, independent development, and consistent versioning. Include diagrams showing the relationship between applications and shared packages. Address concerns like package isolation, dependency management, and development workflow across different parts of the monorepo.

wiki_catalogs.name: NestJS Module Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the NestJS module structure in prj-core. Describe how the application is organized into feature modules (auth, users, tenants, etc.) following NestJS best practices. Document the module hierarchy, imports, providers, controllers, and exports configuration. Explain the purpose of each module and its responsibilities within the domain-driven design context. Detail how modules communicate with each other through dependency injection. Include examples of module relationships and demonstrate proper module organization patterns used in the codebase. Address common issues in module organization and provide guidance on creating new modules.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Frontend
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the admin frontend application in prj-core. Describe the high-level design using React with Vite, including the routing structure implemented through routeTree.gen.ts and nested route organization. Document the component-based architecture, layout patterns, and authentication flow implementation. Explain the integration with shared packages including ui components and shared-api-client for API communication. Detail the state management approach using MobX stores from ui, theming implementation, and responsive design considerations. Include information about build configuration via vite.config.ts, styling approach with Tailwind CSS, and how the admin interface handles tenant selection and role-based access control. Provide examples of key components and their interactions with backend services.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Client Package
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the shared-api-client package in prj-core. Explain its purpose as an automatically generated API client from OpenAPI specifications using Orval, enabling type-safe communication between frontend applications and the NestJS backend. Document the architecture including the use of customAxios for HTTP configuration, the model directory containing TypeScript interfaces for all API request/response payloads, and apis.ts which exports all generated service functions. Detail the implementation of environment-specific Orval configurations (dev, stg, prod) that generate the API client code. Provide practical examples of how to import and use the API client in both the admin and mobile applications, including usage with React Query for data fetching. Explain the code generation workflow, versioning strategy, and how to extend the client for new endpoints. Include troubleshooting guidance for common issues like type mismatches, authentication errors, and regeneration problems, as well as performance considerations around bundle size and lazy loading.

wiki_catalogs.name: Assignments API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create RESTful API documentation for the Assignments API endpoints. Document all CRUD operations including creating, retrieving, updating, and deleting assignments. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, request parameters (path/query/body), and response schemas for each endpoint. Include authentication requirements (JWT), required roles/permissions, and access controls. Document request body structure for assignment creation, including required fields, validation rules, and constraints. Detail response formats with success and error cases, including status codes (200, 201, 400, 401, 403, 404). Provide examples of request and response payloads in JSON format. Include query parameters for filtering, sorting, and pagination as defined in query-assignment.dto. Add sample curl commands for common operations. Document relationships with other entities like users, programs, and routines.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Categories
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the component categorization system in prj-core's ui package. Explain the purpose of organizing components into logical categories (cell, inputs, layout, ui) for maintainability and discoverability. Document the architecture of each category, implementation details of representative components, and usage patterns. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase. Provide practical examples of how to import and use components from each category. Document the index.ts export pattern, storybook integration for each component type, and best practices for component selection based on use case. Address accessibility considerations and responsive design patterns specific to each category.

wiki_catalogs.name: Server Docker Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the NestJS server Docker configuration in prj-core. Explain the multi-stage Docker build process, base image selection (node:18-alpine), and layer optimization strategies. Document the build context, working directory setup, dependency installation process with pnpm, and source code copying patterns. Detail the production build process using Turborepo, environment variable configuration, and port exposure (3000). Explain the runtime configuration, health checks, and container security considerations. Include optimization techniques such as layer caching, minimal image size, and production-specific dependencies. Provide examples of build commands, image tagging conventions, and best practices for containerizing NestJS applications in this monorepo context.

wiki_catalogs.name: Monorepo Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the prj-core monorepo architecture using Turborepo and pnpm workspaces. Describe the high-level design that enables shared code management across multiple applications through a unified dependency graph. Document the task orchestration configuration in turbo.json, including build, test, and dev pipelines with their caching mechanisms and execution order. Explain the workspace configuration in pnpm-workspace.yaml that defines the package boundaries and dependency linking. Illustrate how changes in shared packages (ui, shared-utils, shared-schema) automatically trigger dependent app rebuilds. Detail the technical decisions behind choosing Turborepo for incremental builds and pnpm for efficient dependency management, including trade-offs regarding complexity versus performance gains. Provide component breakdowns showing the dependency relationships between apps and packages, and explain how this architecture supports independent deployment of applications while maintaining code consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Admin Interface component of prj-core. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of the React-based admin application built with Vite, including its bootstrap process in main.tsx, routing configuration through routeTree.gen.ts, and authentication flow integration. Document the relationship between the admin interface and shared frontend components, particularly the use of AppProviders for state management. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how the login route and tenant selection are handled. Explain the integration with the shared-api-client for API communication and the use of ui components for UI consistency. Address common issues such as route configuration errors and authentication token handling, providing solutions from actual implementation patterns. Make content accessible to beginners with clear explanations of the component hierarchy while providing technical depth on performance optimization and error boundaries for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Shared API Client
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the shared-api-client package in prj-core. Detail the relationship between shared-api-client and the NestJS backend's Swagger documentation. Address common issues such as API versioning, handling breaking changes, and regeneration strategies, providing solutions for maintaining client-server contract consistency. wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Application
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Admin Application in prj-core. wiki_catalogs.name: Auth Module

wiki_catalogs.name: Domain Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive RESTful API documentation for domain-specific endpoints in prj-core. wiki_catalogs.name: Routing Structure

Document the custom hooks useAdminLoginRoute and useAdminTenantSelectRoute for programmatic navigation within the admin context.

wiki_catalogs.name: Turborepo Configuration

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend-Backend Communication

wiki_catalogs.name: Users Endpoints

Thoroughly explain the implementation of the categories.tsx component, including its interface for viewing, creating, and managing categories within the space service context. Document the category data model, its hierarchical structure, classification types, and the API endpoints used for retrieval and modification. Include concrete examples from the codebase demonstrating tree-based navigation patterns, drag-and-drop reordering if implemented, and integration with ui components like DataGrid and Form inputs. Explain how this component leverages the shared-api-client for type-safe operations and handles asynchronous data loading and error states. Address common issues such as maintaining category hierarchy integrity, handling circular references, and implementing search/filter functionality across nested categories, providing solutions based on actual implementation patterns. Make content accessible to beginners with clear visual representations of the category tree while providing technical depth on efficient rendering strategies for deep hierarchies for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Programs Module
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Programs Module of prj-core. Thoroughly explain the implementation details of program creation, management, and lifecycle. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing program creation, status management, and integration with routines and categories. Explain how programs serve as containers for structured content sequences. Address common issues such as program versioning, status transitions, and dependency management, providing solutions from actual implementation patterns. wiki_catalogs.name: File Classification System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the File Classification System in prj-core. Address use cases such as content filtering, access control based on classification, and automated tagging workflows. Discuss the database schema design for classifications, including constraints and indexing strategies for efficient querying. Provide guidance on extending the classification system with custom taxonomies and integrating with metadata extraction services.

Describe the UI layout, pagination implementation, and search/filtering capabilities for grounds management. wiki_catalogs.name: DateCell
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the DateCell component in the ui library. Include examples of how the component formats dates according to different locales and business requirements. Explain integration with date libraries, handling of invalid dates, null/undefined values, and theming support. wiki_catalogs.name: Development Environment Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on setting up the development environment for prj-core. Explain the prerequisites (Node.js, pnpm, Docker), installation process, and initial configuration. Document the monorepo setup with pnpm workspaces, code formatting with Biome, and task orchestration with Turborepo. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase. Provide practical step-by-step examples of the setup process, including common issues and their solutions. Document environment-specific configurations for different operating systems. Include troubleshooting guidance for common setup problems and performance considerations for optimal development experience.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the prj-core development workflow. Explain the complete process from initial setup to daily development tasks and deployment preparation. Document the pnpm-based installation process, concurrent development servers using Turborepo, and environment configuration. Include practical examples of common commands like 'pnpm dev' for starting development servers, 'pnpm build' for production builds, and 'pnpm lint' for code quality checks. Document the relationship between package.json scripts and turbo.json task orchestration. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common setup issues like dependency installation problems or port conflicts. Include performance considerations for optimizing development experience in a monorepo environment with multiple applications running simultaneously.

wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the package management system using pnpm in prj-core. Explain the benefits of pnpm's flat node_modules structure and hard linking for disk space optimization. Document the configuration in .npmrc that standardizes package resolution and registry settings. Include workflows for adding, updating, and removing dependencies across applications and shared packages. Address challenges like version resolution, peer dependencies, and workspace protocol usage. Provide best practices for managing dependencies in a multi-package repository.

Document all operations: GET /routines (list with pagination, filtering by program, status), GET /routines/:id (with exercises), POST /routines (create routine with program association), PATCH /routines/:id (update routine), DELETE /routines/:id. Specify authentication and authorization requirements. Include request schema with name, description, programId, order, and status fields. Detail query parameters for list endpoint including programId filter, status filters, and pagination controls. Document the response structure showing routine details and associated exercises. Provide JSON examples for creating a routine within a program and updating routine sequence. Include error handling for invalid program reference (400) and dependency constraints. Add curl examples for retrieving routines by program and creating new routine.

wiki_catalogs.name: Relation Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the relation models in prj-core's Prisma schema. Explain the implementation of one-to-one, one-to-many, and many-to-many relationships across key entities. Document the use of relation fields, references, and foreign key constraints. Detail cascade delete behaviors, ON UPDATE actions, and referential actions configured in the schema. Provide examples of complex relationship patterns such as self-relations, multiple relations between the same models, and embedded relations. Include guidance on querying related data and optimizing relation performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: User-Tenant Associations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for User-Tenant associations in prj-core. Detail the UserAssociation entity structure, including foreign keys, status fields, and metadata. Document the relationship lifecycle from user invitation to active membership and deactivation. Explain how multiple tenant memberships are handled for individual users. Document the API endpoints that manage user-tenant relationships and their permission requirements. Include information about audit logging for association changes and compliance requirements for membership records.

wiki_catalogs.name: Session Data Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Session entity in prj-core. Detail the Session schema including scheduling information, recurrence patterns, and relationship with Programs. Document the scheduling logic with start/end times, recurring day of week, and repeat cycle types. Explain the recurrence pattern implementation, including daily, weekly, monthly cycles and exception handling. Include validation rules for time constraints, recurrence rules, and conflict detection. Document performance considerations for querying Sessions by date ranges and indexing strategies for calendar views. Explain the relationship between Sessions and user/tenant contexts.

Explain the relationship between classifications and their respective entities (FileClassification to File, SpaceClassification to Space). Include data validation rules ensuring classification type consistency and required field completeness. Document indexing strategies on type and name fields for filtering performance and implement soft-delete functionality with audit trails.

Document all operations: GET /categories (list with pagination, filtering by type), GET /categories/:id, POST /categories (create category), PATCH /categories/:id (update category), DELETE /categories/:id. Specify authentication via JWT and hierarchical category support. Include request schema with name, description, type (program, exercise, space, file), parentId for hierarchy, and display properties. Detail query parameters for list endpoint including type filter, hierarchical retrieval, and pagination. Document response structure with category details and tree relationships. Provide JSON examples for creating a hierarchical category structure and updating category display properties. Include error responses for circular references (400) and type conflicts (409). Add curl examples for retrieving categories by type and creating nested categories.

wiki_catalogs.name: Testing Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the testing strategy in prj-core. Explain the purpose and scope of testing across the monorepo, covering unit, integration, and E2E testing. Document the testing architecture with Vitest for frontend and Jest for backend, implementation details, and usage patterns. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase. Provide practical examples of writing and running different types of tests. Document test organization, mocking strategies, and coverage requirements. Include troubleshooting guidance for common testing issues and performance considerations for test execution speed.

wiki_catalogs.name: Tenants API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive REST API documentation for the Tenants API. Document all endpoints for tenant management including creation, retrieval, update, and deletion operations. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, request parameters (path/query/body), and response schemas. Include authentication requirements (JWT) and authorization rules, particularly for multi-tenancy operations. Detail the request payload structure for tenant creation, including required fields, validation rules, data types, and constraints. Document response formats for single tenants and paginated lists, including success and error responses with status codes (200, 201, 400, 401, 403, 404). Provide JSON examples for requests and responses. Include query parameters for filtering, sorting, and pagination from query-tenant.dto. Add sample curl commands for common operations. Document tenant associations with users, spaces, and programs in a multi-tenant architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Shared Utility Functions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create documentation for the Shared Utility Functions package in prj-core. Describe its collection of reusable utility functions organized by concern including date/time manipulation, data validation, logging, and environment detection. Document the functionality, parameters, and return values of key utilities. Explain how these functions promote code reuse and consistency across applications. Detail the testing strategy with Vitest for utility functions. Include usage examples demonstrating common patterns. Describe the development workflow for adding new utilities while maintaining backward compatibility and type safety.

wiki_catalogs.name: Roles Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive RESTful API documentation for role management endpoints. Document all operations: GET /roles (list with pagination, filtering by category, group), GET /roles/:id, POST /roles (create role), PATCH /roles/:id (update role), DELETE /roles/:id. Specify authentication and administrative authorization requirements. Include request schema with name, description, category, group, permissions/abilities, and status. Detail query parameters for list endpoint including category, group filters, and permission-based filtering. Document response structure with role details and associated permissions. Provide JSON examples for creating a role with ability assignments and updating role permissions. Include error handling for permission conflicts (400) and protected role modifications (403). Add curl examples for retrieving roles by category and creating custom roles.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the deployment configuration of prj-core. Describe the high-level deployment design with Docker containers, architectural patterns (containerization with Docker, orchestration with docker-compose), and system boundaries. Document component interactions between containers, data flows, and integration patterns with external systems. Explain technical decisions, trade-offs, and constraints of the deployment approach. Include infrastructure requirements, scalability considerations, and deployment topology. Provide system context diagrams and container breakdowns. Address cross-cutting concerns like environment variables, secrets management, and health checks. Document technology stack, third-party dependencies, and version compatibility for the deployment infrastructure.

wiki_catalogs.name: Roles API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed REST API documentation for the Roles API endpoints. Document all CRUD operations for role management with HTTP methods, URL patterns, request parameters (path/query/body), and response schemas. Specify authentication (JWT) and authorization requirements for each endpoint, particularly regarding role-based access control. Detail the request payload structure for role creation, including required fields, validation rules, data types, and constraints. Document response formats for single roles and paginated lists, including success and error responses with appropriate status codes (200, 201, 400, 401, 403, 404). Provide JSON examples for requests and responses. Include query parameters for filtering, sorting, and pagination from query-role.dto. Add sample curl commands for common operations. Document role associations, classifications, and relationships with users, groups, and permissions in the access control system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Shared Configuration Variables
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create documentation for the Shared Configuration Variables package in prj-core. Describe its role in centralizing environment-agnostic configuration such as API endpoints and route names. Document the structure of endpoints.ts for service URLs and route-names.ts for application navigation paths. Explain how this package enables consistent routing and API consumption across applications. Detail the build process with tsup.config.ts that packages these variables for consumption. Include examples of how other packages and applications import and use these shared variables. Describe the workflow for updating configuration values and managing backward compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contribution Guidelines
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on contributing to prj-core. Explain the contribution process from setting up the development environment to submitting pull requests. Document the code style enforced by Biome, branching strategy, commit message conventions, and pull request review process. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase. Provide practical examples of making different types of contributions (bug fixes, feature additions, documentation updates). Document versioning strategy, backward compatibility requirements, and release process. Include troubleshooting guidance for common contribution issues and best practices for maintaining code quality.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive REST API documentation for the Authentication API. Document all endpoints for user authentication including login, logout, token refresh, and password management operations. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, request parameters (path/query/body), and response schemas. Include detailed authentication flow documentation with JWT token issuance, validation, and expiration. Detail the request payload structure for login, including required fields and validation rules. Document response formats with access and refresh tokens, including success and error responses with appropriate status codes (200, 201, 400, 401, 403). Provide JSON examples for requests and responses. Add sample curl commands for authentication flows. Document token refresh mechanisms, password reset functionality, and security considerations such as rate limiting and brute force protection.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# PRJ Core Monorepo: Comprehensive Project Analysis

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
PRJ Core is a full-stack monorepo that serves as the central development hub for a comprehensive application ecosystem. The repository integrates multiple applications and shared packages to provide a unified platform for administration, mobile access, and component development.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Implement a scalable monorepo architecture using Turborepo and pnpm for efficient dependency management
- Provide a consistent development experience across frontend, backend, and mobile applications
- Enable code sharing and reuse through well-defined shared packages
- Support rapid development with hot-reloading and integrated testing workflows
- Facilitate API-first development with generated API clients from OpenAPI specifications

### Target Audience
- Frontend developers working on admin and mobile interfaces
- Backend engineers developing and maintaining the NestJS API
- UI/UX designers utilizing Storybook for component development
- DevOps engineers managing CI/CD pipelines and deployment
- Full-stack developers contributing across multiple application layers

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The project follows a monorepo architecture with clear separation between applications and shared packages:

```mermaid
graph TD
    SharedLib[Shared Libraries] --> Admin[Admin App]
    SharedLib --> Mobile[Mobile App]
    SharedLib --> Server[Server API]
    SharedLib --> Storybook[Storybook]
    Server --> Database[(Database)]
    Admin --> Server
    Mobile --> Server
    Storybook --> SharedLib
    
    subgraph "Applications"
        Admin
        Mobile
        Server
        Storybook
    end
    
    subgraph "Shared Packages"
        SharedLib
        SharedApiClient["@shared/api-client"]
        SharedFrontend["@shared/frontend"]
        SharedUtils["@shared/utils"]
        SharedTypes["@shared/types"]
        SharedVars["@shared/vars"]
        SharedSchema["@shared/schema"]
    end
```

### Design Patterns
The architecture employs several key design patterns:

- **Monorepo Pattern**: Centralized repository with multiple applications and shared packages
- **Microservices-inspired Module Architecture**: Server application organized into feature modules
- **Provider Pattern**: Global state and context management through AppProviders
- **Repository Pattern**: Data access through Prisma with service layer abstraction
- **API Client Generation**: Automated API client generation from OpenAPI specs using Orval

### System Relationships
The system components interact through well-defined interfaces:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Admin UI] -->|HTTP Requests| B[API Layer]
    C[Mobile App] -->|HTTP Requests| B
    D[Storybook] --> E[Shared Components]
    B --> F[Business Logic]
    F --> G[Data Access]
    G --> H[(Database)]
    I[Shared API Client] --> B
    J[Shared Frontend] --> A
    J --> C
    J --> D
    K[Shared Schema] --> G
    L[Shared Utils] --> All[All Components]
```

### Data Flow
The data flow follows a predictable pattern from user interaction to persistence:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    User->>+Admin UI: Interact with UI
    Admin UI->>+Shared API Client: Call API method
    Shared API Client->>+Server: HTTP Request
    Server->>+Business Logic: Process request
    Business Logic->>+Data Access: Query/Update
    Data Access->>+Database: Execute query
    Database-->>-Data Access: Return data
    Data Access-->>-Business Logic: Processed data
    Business Logic-->>-Server: Response
    Server-->>-Shared API Client: HTTP Response
    Shared API Client-->>-Admin UI: Data
    Admin UI-->>-User: Update interface
```

## 3. Implementation Details

### Main Entry Points

#### Server Bootstrap
The NestJS application bootstraps with comprehensive configuration for logging, validation, and API documentation:

```typescript
async function bootstrap() {
  const app = await NestFactory.create<NestExpressApplication>(AppModule, {
    bufferLogs: true,
  });

  app.useLogger(app.get(Logger));
  app.use(cookieParser());
  app.set("query parser", "extended");
  
  app.useGlobalFilters(
    new AllExceptionsFilter(httpAdapterHost.httpAdapter),
    new PrismaClientExceptionFilter(httpAdapterHost.httpAdapter)
  );

  app.useGlobalPipes(
    new ValidationPipe({
      transform: true,
      whitelist: true,
    })
  );

  const config = new DocumentBuilder()
    .setVersion("1.0.0")
    .addBearerAuth()
    .build();

  const document = SwaggerModule.createDocument(app, config, options);
  SwaggerModule.setup("api", app, document);

  app.enableCors({
    origin: [
      "http://localhost:4173",
      "http://localhost:6006",
      // ... other origins
    ],
    credentials: true,
  });

  await app.listen(port);
}
```

Sources:
- [main.ts](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/apps/server/src/main.ts#L1-L76)

#### Admin Application Bootstrap
The React admin application initializes with shared providers for global state management:

```typescript
const rootElement = document.getElementById("root")!;

if (!rootElement.innerHTML) {
	ReactDOM.createRoot(rootElement).render(
		<AppProviders>
			<App />
		</AppProviders>,
	);
}
```

Sources:
- [main.tsx](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/apps/admin/src/main.tsx#L1-L13)

### Core Modules

#### AppProviders
The shared AppProviders component wraps applications with essential context providers:

```typescript
export const AppProviders = (props: AppProvidersProps) => {
	const { children } = props;

	return (
		<QueryProvider>
			<NuqsAdapter>
				<AuthProvider>{children}</AuthProvider>
				<ToastProvider placement="bottom-center" />
			</NuqsAdapter>
		</QueryProvider>
	);
};
```

This pattern enables consistent state management, authentication, and UI feedback across applications.

Sources:
- [AppProviders.tsx](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/packages/ui/src/provider/AppProviders/AppProviders.tsx#L1-L20)

#### AppModule
The NestJS AppModule organizes feature modules with a hierarchical routing structure:

```typescript
@Module({
	imports: [
		...modules,
		CaslModule,
		GroundsModule,
		// ... other modules
		RouterModule.register([
			{
				path: "api",
				children: [
					{
						path: "v1",
						children: [
							{
								path: "tenants",
								module: TenantsModule,
							},
							{
								path: "auth",
								module: AuthModule,
							},
							// ... other routes
						],
					},
				],
			},
		]),
	],
})
```

Sources:
- [app.module.ts](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/apps/server/src/module/app.module.ts#L1-L177)

### Configuration Approach

#### Root Package Configuration
The root package.json defines monorepo-wide scripts using Turborepo:

```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "build": "turbo build",
    "clean": "turbo clean",
    "start:dev": "turbo start:dev --no-cache  --continue",
    "lint": "turbo lint",
    "lint:fix": "turbo lint:fix",
    "format": "turbo format",
    "test": "turbo test",
    "storybook": "pnpm -C apps/mobile storybook"
  }
}
```

Sources:
- [package.json](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/package.json#L1-L26)

#### API Client Generation
The shared API client uses Orval for code generation from OpenAPI specifications:

```json
"scripts": {
  "codegen:dev": "orval --config orval.dev.config.js",
  "codegen:stg": "orval --config orval.stg.config.js",
  "codegen:prod": "orval --config orval.prod.config.js",
  "codegen": "npm run codegen:dev",
  "prebuild": "npm run clean:dist",
  "prepack": "npm run build:prod"
}
```

Sources:
- [package.json](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/packages/shared-api-client/package.json#L1-L63)

### External Dependencies

#### Server Dependencies
The server application leverages several key external packages:

```json
"dependencies": {
  "@aws-sdk/client-s3": "^3.844.0",
  "@casl/ability": "^6.7.3",
  "@nestjs-modules/mailer": "^2.0.2",
  "@nestjs/common": "^11.1.3",
  "@prisma/client": "catalog:",
  "axios": "^1.11.0",
  "bcrypt": "^6.0.0",
  "class-transformer": "^0.5.1",
  "class-validator": "^0.14.2",
  "nestjs-cls": "^6.0.1",
  "nestjs-pino": "^4.4.0",
  "nestjs-prisma": "^0.25.0"
}
```

Sources:
- [package.json](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/apps/server/package.json#L1-L104)

#### Admin Dependencies
The admin application uses modern frontend libraries:

```json
"dependencies": {
  "@dnd-kit/core": "^6.3.1",
  "@heroui/react": "catalog:",
  "@internationalized/date": "^3.8.2",
  "@shared/api-client": "workspace:*",
  "@shared/frontend": "workspace:*",
  "@tanstack/react-query": "5.83.0",
  "@tanstack/react-router": "^1.130.2",
  "mobx": "catalog:",
  "mobx-react-lite": "catalog:",
  "react": "catalog:",
  "react-dom": "catalog:"
}
```

Sources:
- [package.json](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/apps/admin/package.json#L1-L69)

### Integration Points

#### Authentication Flow
The authentication flow demonstrates integration between multiple components:

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Admin Login Page] --> B[useAdminAuthLoginRoute]
    B --> C[login Mutation]
    C --> D[Shared API Client]
    D --> E[Server Auth Endpoint]
    E --> F[Prisma Database]
    F --> G[NestJS AuthModule]
    G --> H[JWT Generation]
    H --> I[Client Storage]
```

#### Component Reuse
Shared components are reused across applications:

```typescript
// In Admin App
import { AdminAuthLoginPage } from "@shared/frontend";

// The shared component itself imports from the admin app
// This suggests a potential circular dependency that should be addressed
import { useAdminAuthLoginRoute } from "../../../../../apps/admin/src/hooks/useAdminLoginRoute";
```

Sources:
- [AdminAuthLoginPage.tsx](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/packages/ui/src/components/page/AdminAuthLoginPage.tsx#L1-L29)

## 4. Key Features

### Authentication System
The authentication system provides a consistent login experience across applications:

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> LoginIdle
    LoginIdle --> LoginProcessing: User submits credentials
    LoginProcessing --> LoginSuccess: Valid credentials
    LoginProcessing --> LoginError: Invalid credentials
    LoginSuccess --> TenantSelect: Proceed to tenant selection
    LoginError --> LoginIdle: Display error message
    TenantSelect --> [*]: Complete authentication
```

#### Implementation Highlights
The login functionality combines React Query for data fetching with MobX for state management:

```typescript
const useActions = () => {
	const { mutateAsync: loginMutation } = useMutation({
		mutationFn: login,
	});

	const navigate = useNavigate();

	const goToTenantSelect = () => {
		navigate({
			to: "/admin/auth/login/tenant-select",
		});
	};

	return {
		goToTenantSelect,
		loginMutation,
	};
};
```

Sources:
- [login.tsx](/Users/wallykim/dev/prj-core/apps/admin/src/routes/admin/auth/login.tsx#L1-L88)

#### Usage Example
The component composition demonstrates the integration of state, actions, and handlers:

```typescript
const useAdminAuthLoginRoute = () => {
	const state = useState();
	const actions = useActions();
	const handlers = useHandlers({
		state,
		actions,
	});

	return {
		state,
		actions,
		handlers,
	};
};
```

### API Client Generation
The automated API client generation ensures type safety and reduces boilerplate:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[OpenAPI Specification] --> B[Orval Configuration]
    B --> C[Code Generation]
    C --> D[TypeScript API Client]
    D --> E[React Query Hooks]
    E --> F[Type-Safe API Calls]
    F --> G[Compile-Time Validation]
```

### Shared Component Library
The shared frontend package provides reusable UI components:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Shared Frontend] --> B[Components]
    A --> C[Providers]
    A --> D[Store]
    A --> E[Utils]
    
    B --> F[Layout Components]
    B --> G[Form Components]
    B --> H[UI Components]
    B --> I[Page Templates]
    
    C --> J[AuthProvider]
    C --> K[QueryProvider]
    C --> L[AppProviders]
    
    D --> M[Auth Store]
    D --> N[Navigation Store]
    D --> O[Token Store]
    
    F --> Admin
    F --> Mobile
    G --> Admin
    G --> Mobile
    H --> Admin
    H --> Mobile
    I --> Admin
    J --> Admin
    J --> Mobile
    K --> Admin
    K --> Mobile
    M --> Admin
    M --> Mobile
```

### Development Workflow
The project provides a streamlined development experience:

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Developer] --> B[pnpm install]
    B --> C[pnpm dev]
    C --> D[Concurrent Development Servers]
    D --> E[Admin: Vite]
    D --> F[Server: NestJS Watch]
    D --> G[Mobile: Expo]
    E --> H[Hot Reload]
    F --> H
    G --> H
    H --> I[Real-time Updates]
```

The `pnpm dev` command leverages Turborepo to start all development servers concurrently, enabling full-stack development with hot-reloading across all applications.
</blog>

wiki_readme.content:
# PRJ Core Monorepo

This repository hosts a fullstack monorepo managed with [Turborepo](https://turbo.build/) and [pnpm](https://pnpm.io/). It contains multiple applications and shared packages used across the project.

## Repository Structure

### Applications
- **admin**  React + Vite based admin UI.
- **server**  [NestJS](https://nestjs.com/) backend API.
- **storybook**  Next.js application for UI component previews.

### Packages
- **@shared/frontend**  shared React component library.
- **@shared/api-client**  generated API client.
- **@shared/utils**  utility functions.
- **@shared/types**  shared TypeScript types.
- **@shared/vars**  common variables/constants.
- **@shared/specs**  OpenAPI specifications.

Additional documentation can be found in the [`docs`](./docs) directory.

## Getting Started

Install dependencies and start development servers:

```bash
pnpm install
pnpm dev
```

Use the scripts defined in the root `package.json` to build or test the project:

```bash
pnpm build   # build all packages and apps
pnpm test    # run tests
pnpm clean   # remove generated artifacts
```

Dockerfiles and Jenkins pipelines for building production images are located in the `devops` folder.

## License

[ISC](https://opensource.org/licenses/ISC)
